fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal {C} is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a regular functor and f\colon A\to B be a morphism in \mathcal {C}. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F(\mathsf {Img}(f))F(\vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(Ff) \cong F(\mathsf {Img}(f)).

A category \mathcal {C} is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf {Sub}(A) \hookrightarrow {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf {Img}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) for all objects A \in \mathcal {C}.

A category \mathcal {C} is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F\colon \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be a regular functor and f\colon A\to B be a morphism in \mathcal {C}. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F(\mathsf {Img}(f))F(\vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(Ff) \cong F(\mathsf {Img}(f)).

fr:title.text: Equivalent condition for the existence of images

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalent condition for the existence of images

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. Then \mathcal {C} has images iff for each morphism f\colon A\to B, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a left adjoint \exists _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B).
By , the pullback functor f^{*}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} admits \Sigma _{f}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} as a left adjoint.

Let g\colon B'\rightarrowtail B be an arbitrary object in \mathsf {Sub}(B). We need to construct a functor \mathsf {Img}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(B) so that each morphism f \to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf {Img}(f) \to g in \mathsf {Sub}(B).
Let f \to g be an arbitrary morphism in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. Then this corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf {id}_{A} \to f^{*}(g) as follows:

This then corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A}) \to g under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}. Thus, we define \mathsf {Img} by the assignment f \mapsto \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A}). This assignment can be trivially extended to a functor: since the category \mathsf {Sub}(B) is a preorder, every morphism f \to f' in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} has to be mapped to the unique morphism \mathsf {Img}(f) \to \mathsf {Img}(f') in \mathsf {Sub}(B). This morphism must exist. Indeed, it is the lifting of \mathsf {Img}(f) against \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f')} depicted in the following diagram.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A', nw/style = pullback, sw = A, ne = B', se = B, north = \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f')}, east = \mathsf {Img}(f'), east/style = {>->}, south = \mathsf {Img}(f), south/style = {>->}, } \draw [->,morphism,exists] (sw) to (ne); \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can now extract the components of the unit and the counit from this correspondence.

html:td.fr:p: Let f\colon A\to B be an object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. The identity morphism \mathsf {id}\colon \mathsf {Img}(f)\to \mathsf {Img}(f) is, by definition, the identity morphism \mathsf {id}\colon \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A})\to \mathsf {Img}(f), which corresponds to the unit \eta _{\mathsf {id}_{A}}\colon \mathsf {id}_{A}\to f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(f)) of the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

Then since \mathsf {Img}(f) is monic, \eta _{\mathsf {id}_{A}} corresponds to a unique morphism \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f)}\eta _{\mathsf {id}_{A}}\colon f\to \mathsf {Img}(f), where \varepsilon is the counit of the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*}. This defines the component of \vartheta at f. This is precisely the lifting of f against \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f)}.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A', nw/style = pullback, sw = A, ne = B', se = B, north = \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f)}, east = \mathsf {Img}(f), east/style = {>->}, south = f, } \draw [->,morphism,exists] (sw) to node[desc] {$\vartheta _{f}$} (ne); \end {tikzpicture}

html:td.fr:p: Let f\colon A\rightarrowtail B be an object in \mathsf {Sub}(B). Then the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{f}\colon f\to f corresponds to a unique morphism s\colon \mathsf {id}_{A}\to f^{*}(f) by the universal property of pullbacks.
This morphism corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A}) \to f under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}, which we take as the component of \zeta at f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal {C} has images, then we may define \exists _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B) as the following composite:
Let i_{A}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\hookrightarrow {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} and i_{B}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\hookrightarrow {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} be the inclusion functors. Note that
Since f^{*}i_{B} \cong i_{A}f^{*} by construction, we have

Let \eta and \varepsilon be the unit and counit of this adjunction respectively. Since \mathsf {Sub}(A) is a full subcategory of {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}, there is a natural isomorphism \iota \colon \mathsf {id}_{{{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}}\stackrel {\sim }{\smash {\longrightarrow }\rule {0pt}{0.4ex}}i_{A}. Then we can define \eta ' as follows:
Then \eta ' and \varepsilon form the unit and counit of the adjunction \mathsf {Img}\Sigma _{f}i_{A} \dashv f^{*}.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with images and equalizers. Then every morphism of \mathcal {C} can be factored as a cover followed by a monomorphism. Moreover, this factorization is unique up to isomorphism in the sense that if A \twoheadrightarrow C \rightarrowtail B and A \twoheadrightarrow C' \rightarrowtail B are both cover-mono factorizations of the same morphism, then C \cong C'.

By the construction of images, every morphism f\colon A\to B can be factored as \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}, where \vartheta is the unit of the image adjunction. \mathsf {Img}(f) is monic by construction and \vartheta _{f} is a cover by .

To show the second half of the lemma, it suffices to show that every cover-mono factorization of a morphism f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Let hg be a cover-mono factorization of f. Then by the universal property of adjunction, there is a morphism s in \mathsf {Sub}(B) such that s\vartheta _{f} = g. By the definition of \mathsf {Sub}(B), we also have hs = \mathsf {Img}(f). Then, it follows that s is monic.
Since g is extremal, s must be an isomorphism.
A category \mathcal {C} is regular iff it is cartesian and has images that commute with pullbacks, i.e., the following diagram commutes up to isomorphism for any object f \in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}, sw = {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}, ne = \mathsf {Sub}(B), se = \mathsf {Sub}(A), north = \mathsf {Img}, south = \mathsf {Img}, west = f^{*}, east = f^{*}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that \mathcal {C} is a cartesian category with images that commute with pullbacks. Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism and g\colon B'\twoheadrightarrow B be a cover. Then note that \mathsf {Img}(g) is an isomorphism. Since images commute with pullbacks by hypothesis, we can form the following diagram.

Since isomorphisms are stable under pullback, f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) is also an isomorphism. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) is an isomorphism. Then since f^{*}(g) is the composite of two covers, it is itself a cover.

If \mathcal {C} is regular, then by , the unit \vartheta \colon \mathsf {id}\to \mathsf {Img} consists of covers. Let f\colon A\to B be any morphism in \mathcal {C} and g\colon B'\to B be an object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. By , g can be factored as \vartheta _{g}\mathsf {Img}(g). Form the following pullbacks. Note that since covers are stable under pullback by hypothesis, \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is also a cover. Then by the pasting lemma, the composite f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) \circ \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is isomorphic to f^{*}(g) in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}.
Thus, f^{*}(g) admits another cover-mono factorization.
Then by uniqueness, C \cong \underline {A'}. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) \cong f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)).

Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism in a regular category. Then for any two subobjects A' \rightarrowtail A and B' \rightarrowtail B, we have \exists _{f}(A' \cap f^{*}(B')) \cong \exists _{f}(A') \cap B' in \mathsf {Sub}(B), where \exists _{f} is the left adjoint of f^{*} constructed in .
By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B'
Form the following diagram, where the front, left, and right faces are pullbacks.

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B')). Thus, by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B' as required.

fr:title.text: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a cover iff \mathcal {C} satisfies y\colon B|\top \vdash \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y in its internal language.
Suppose that f is a cover. Let e = (b,a)\colon E\to B \times A be the interpretation of f(x) = y in \mathcal {C}. Note that a is an isomorphism since the following is also an equalizer diagram.
By , {\mathopen {}\llbracket y\colon B.\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of the following composite.
By assumption, fa = b. Thus, the image of b coincides with that of fa.
Since a is an isomorphism, it follows that the image of f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(b). Thus, \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism.
Assume the converse. Then the identity morphism factors through \mathsf {Img}(b), i.e., \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism. Thus, it follows that f is a cover.

fr:title.text: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to C is the composite of g\colon A\to B and h\colon B\to C iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = h(g(x)) in its internal language.

Suppose that f = hg. Then {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket h\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket g\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = hg and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = f. Thus, the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the terminal object, and the result follows immediately.

Suppose the converse. Then the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Thus, it follows that f = hg.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a monomorphism iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x,x'\colon A|f(x) = f(x') \vdash x = x' in its internal language.

Suppose that f is monic. Let e\colon E\rightarrowtail A \times A be the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{1} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{2}. Then it follows that f\pi _{1}e = f\pi _{2}e. Since f is monic, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e. Then it follows that e factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket x = x'\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}.
Assume the converse. Suppose that fu = fv for some parallel pair of morphisms u,v\colon C\rightrightarrows A. Then it follows that (u,v) factors through e.
Thus, u = \pi _{1}(u,v) = \pi _{1}ew and v = \pi _{2}(u,v) = \pi _{2}ew. By assumption, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e so u = v.

fr:title.text: Identity morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to A is the identity morphism iff x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = x is satisfied in the internal language of \mathcal {C}.

Suppose that f is the identity morphism. Then by , {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is \mathsf {id}_{A} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. But the equalizer with itself is the terminal object. Thus, \top \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} in \mathsf {Sub}(A) as required.

Conversely, suppose that the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) (i.e., the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A}) factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Then it follows that \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Since {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = \mathsf {id}_{A} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f, it follows that f = \mathsf {id}_{A}.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category and R \in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times B) be a relation satisfying the following sequents:

fr:ul.fr:li: Functional: x\colon A, y\colon B, y'\colon B|R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y') \vdash y = y'

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then there is a unique morphism f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} such that x\colon A,y\colon B|R \dashv \vdash f(x) = y is satisfied.

Suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (a, b)\colon R\to A \times B. Then R(x,y) and R(x,y') may be respectively interpreted (up to isomorphism) as (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2}) and (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1}), where \rho _{1} and \rho _{2} are the product projections out of R \times B.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { width = 3cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y)}, west = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} } \qquad \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R \times B}, nw/style = pullback, ne = R, sw = {A \times B \times B}, se = {A \times B}, north = {\rho _{1}}, south = {(x, y')}, west = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})}, west/style = {>->}, east = {(a,b)}, east/style = {>->} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (up to isomorphism) either composite of the following square.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {R \times B}, sw = {R \times B}, se = {A \times B \times B}, north = {(\gamma ',\beta ')}, south = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west = {(\gamma ,\beta )}, east = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first sequent demands that \gamma = \gamma ' and that \beta = \beta '. Suppose that au = av. Then (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})(u,bv) = (au,bv,bu) = (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})(v,bu). Thus, u = v.
Note that {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\colon A.\exists y\colon B.\mkern 5muR\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of a. This is an isomorphism by the second sequent. Thus, a is a cover.

Since a is a monic cover, it is an isomorphism. Thus, we can define f := ba^{-1}. Note that (a,b) is an equalizer of f\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Thus, the required sequent is satisfied. Suppose that g\colon A\to B also satisfies the required sequent. Then (a,b) is an equalizer of g\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Since (\mathsf {id},f) factors through (a,b) via a^{-1}, g\pi _{1}(\mathsf {id},f) = \pi _{2}(\mathsf {id},f). Then it follows that f = g.

fr:title.text: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} has comprehension schema.

Each fiber \mathsf {Sub}(A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal {C}. By , each f^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then by construction the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(X) is just \mathsf {Img}, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.

Let (a,b)\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times A be an effective equivalence relation in a regular category. Then a,b\colon R\rightrightarrows A admit a coequalizer d. Moreover, (a,b) is a kernel pair of d.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, (a,b) is a kernel pair of some morphism. Then the result follows immediately from .

fr:title.text: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a regular category, every kernel pair has a coequalizer. Moreover, the given kernel pair is also a kernel pair of the coequalizer.

Let a,b\colon R\rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a morphism f\colon A\to B. Consider the cover-mono factorization of f: f = f_{m}f_{c}. By , it suffices to show that (a,b) is a kernel pair of f_{c}, i.e., the following diagram is a pullback.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = R, ne = A, sw = A, se = {\mathsf {Img}(f)}, north = b, west = a, south = {f_{c}}, south/style = {cover}, east = {f_{c}}, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, the diagram commutes since fa = f_{m}f_{c}a = f_{m}f_{c}b = fb by definition, and f_{m} is monic. Let h,k\colon C\rightrightarrows A be a pair of morphisms such that f_{c}h = f_{c}k. Then f_{m}f_{c}h = fh = fk = f_{m}f_{c}k. Thus, the unique factor is given by the following pullback.

A regular category \mathcal {C} is said to be coherent if each \mathsf {Sub}(B) has finite unions and each f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B) preserves them. A coherent functor between coherent categories is a regular functor which preserves finite unions.
In a regular category, every cover is a coequalizer of the kernel pair of itself.

Let p,q\colon C\rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a cover f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B and g\colon A\to D be a morphism such that gp = gq. Consider the joint cover-mono factorization of f and g, i.e., the cover-mono factorization of the morphism (f,g)\colon A\to B \times D.

We show that f' and h form a cover-mono factorization of the cover f, so f' is an isomorphism. Suppose that f'a = f'b. We need to show that a = b. To this end, it suffices to show that g'a = g'b since f' and g' are jointly monic. Consider the joint pullback of a and b along h.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = \AA , nw/style = {pullback}, ne = A \times A, sw = E, se = \underline {A} \times \underline {A}, north = {(m,n)}, west = r, west/style = {cover}, south = {(a,b)}, east = h \times h, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that h \times h is a cover by , and since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, r is also a cover. Now we have that
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} fm &= f'hm\\ &= f'ar && \text {by hypothesis $f'a = f'b$}\\ &= f'br\\ &= f'hn\\ &= fn \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, m and n may be expressed in terms of the kernel pair of f.
To show g'a = g'b, it suffices to show g'ar = g'br since r is epic.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} g'ar &= g'hm\\ &= gm\\ &= gps && \text {by hypothesis $gp = gq$}\\ &= gqs\\ &= gn\\ &= g'hn\\ &= g'br \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Finally, g can be factored as follows:
Uniqueness then follows from the fact that f is epic.

Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism in a regular category. Then for any two subobjects A' \rightarrowtail A and B' \rightarrowtail B, we have \exists _{f}(A' \cap f^{*}(B')) \cong \exists _{f}(A') \cap B' in \mathsf {Sub}(B), where \exists _{f} is the left adjoint of f^{*} constructed in .
By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B'
Form the following diagram, where the front, left, and right faces are pullbacks.

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B')). Thus, by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B' as required.
A category \mathcal {C} is regular iff it is cartesian and has images that commute with pullbacks, i.e., the following diagram commutes up to isomorphism for any object f \in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}, sw = {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}, ne = \mathsf {Sub}(B), se = \mathsf {Sub}(A), north = \mathsf {Img}, south = \mathsf {Img}, west = f^{*}, east = f^{*}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that \mathcal {C} is a cartesian category with images that commute with pullbacks. Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism and g\colon B'\twoheadrightarrow B be a cover. Then note that \mathsf {Img}(g) is an isomorphism. Since images commute with pullbacks by hypothesis, we can form the following diagram.

Since isomorphisms are stable under pullback, f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) is also an isomorphism. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) is an isomorphism. Then since f^{*}(g) is the composite of two covers, it is itself a cover.

If \mathcal {C} is regular, then by , the unit \vartheta \colon \mathsf {id}\to \mathsf {Img} consists of covers. Let f\colon A\to B be any morphism in \mathcal {C} and g\colon B'\to B be an object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. By , g can be factored as \vartheta _{g}\mathsf {Img}(g). Form the following pullbacks. Note that since covers are stable under pullback by hypothesis, \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is also a cover. Then by the pasting lemma, the composite f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) \circ \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is isomorphic to f^{*}(g) in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}.
Thus, f^{*}(g) admits another cover-mono factorization.
Then by uniqueness, C \cong \underline {A'}. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) \cong f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)).

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with images and equalizers. Then every morphism of \mathcal {C} can be factored as a cover followed by a monomorphism. Moreover, this factorization is unique up to isomorphism in the sense that if A \twoheadrightarrow C \rightarrowtail B and A \twoheadrightarrow C' \rightarrowtail B are both cover-mono factorizations of the same morphism, then C \cong C'.

By the construction of images, every morphism f\colon A\to B can be factored as \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}, where \vartheta is the unit of the image adjunction. \mathsf {Img}(f) is monic by construction and \vartheta _{f} is a cover by .

To show the second half of the lemma, it suffices to show that every cover-mono factorization of a morphism f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Let hg be a cover-mono factorization of f. Then by the universal property of adjunction, there is a morphism s in \mathsf {Sub}(B) such that s\vartheta _{f} = g. By the definition of \mathsf {Sub}(B), we also have hs = \mathsf {Img}(f). Then, it follows that s is monic.
Since g is extremal, s must be an isomorphism.

An epimorphism f\colon A\twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m\colon C\rightarrowtail B and any morphism g\colon A\to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.

A category \mathcal {C} is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf {Sub}(A) \hookrightarrow {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf {Img}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) for all objects A \in \mathcal {C}.
